resources.string: The L game is considered a simple abstract strategy board game. It was invented by Edward de Bono and was introduced in his book \"The Five-Day Course in Thinking\" (1967). \nRead more in the wikipedia article:
The article includes rules, strategy and analysis of the game.
How to move the L piece
How to move a neutral piece

Click on the squares you want it to occupy. Click again to remove a square. Make sure the squares: 
- Are not occupied by a neutral piece 
- Are not part of the L belonging to the other player 
The new L can re-use squares from the previous position (marked with a light color), but at least ONE square has to be new. 
Click "done" when you are satisfied with the new position. After moving the L you can chose to move one of the two neutral pieces if you want.

Click on the neutral piece you want to move, and then on the new position. Click \"done\" afterwards. \nIf you do not want to move a neutral piece, you can click on \"done\" right away. \nIf you want to move the other neutral piece instead of the one you clicked at, just move it back in place and click on the other one neutral piece instead.
You win when the other person has no place to move their L-piece.
Optional move: Move a neutral (black) piece
Move the L-piece by tapping on white and/or lightly colored squares
